description: Learn how to connect web pages using hyperlinks, anchor tags, and navigation menus.

slides.title: Hyperlinks
slides.content: # The Tag üîó HTML links are hyperlinks. You can click on a link and jump to another document. - The `` tag defines a hyperlink. - The most important attribute is `href`, which indicates the link's destination. ```html Visit Google ``` **Visuals:** Links appear underlined and blue by default.

slides.title: Absolute vs Relative
slides.content: # URL Types üåê ## Absolute URLs A full web address (e.g., `https://www.w3schools.com/`) ```html W3C ``` ## Relative URLs A local link (a link to a page within the same website), without the "https://www..." part. ```html About Us View Banner ```

slides.title: Target Attribute
slides.content: # Opening Links üéØ The `target` attribute specifies where to open the linked document. - `_self` (Default): Opens in the same window/tab. - `_blank`: Opens in a new window or tab. - `_parent`: Opens in the parent frame. - `_top`: Opens in the full body of the window. ```html Google (New Tab) ``` > ‚ö†Ô∏è **Security:** When using `target="_blank"`, consider adding `rel="noopener noreferrer"` for security.

slides.title: Image Links
slides.content: # Image Links üñºÔ∏è You can use an image as a link. Just put the `` tag inside the `` tag. ```html ```

slides.title: Email Links
slides.content: # Mailto Links üìß Use `mailto:` inside the `href` attribute to create a link that opens the user's email program. ```html Send email ``` You can even add a subject: ```html Send email with subject ```

slides.title: Bookmark Links
slides.content:
# Bookmarks (Hash Links) üîñ HTML bookmarks allow readers to jump to specific parts of a webpage. 1. Create a bookmark with the `id` attribute: ```html

Chapter 4

``` 2. Add a link to the bookmark (`#id`): ```html Jump to Chapter 4 ``` You can also link to a bookmark on another page: ```html Jump to Chapter 4 ```

slides.title: Title Attribute
slides.content: # Link Titles üè∑Ô∏è The `title` attribute specifies extra information about an element. The information is most often shown as a **tooltip text** when the mouse moves over the element. ```html Visit our HTML Tutorial ```

slides.title: Button Links
slides.content: # Button as a Link üîò You can use JavaScript to make a button act like a link. ```html ``` Or wrap a button in an `` tag (valid in HTML5): ```html ``` > üí° **Best Practice:** Use `` links styled as buttons with CSS for better accessibility and SEO.

slides.title: Base Path
slides.content: # The Element üè† The `` tag specifies the base URL/target for all relative URLs in a document. - There can be at most one `` element in a document. - It must be inside the `` element. ```html W3Schools ```

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: Links üéì

Connect your pages to the world.

- **Tag:** `<a>` with `href` attribute.
- **Links:** Absolute (`https://`) vs Relative (`page.html`).
- **Target:** `_blank` for new tabs.
- **Hash:** `#id` for jumping within a page.
- **Images:** Can be links too.
